data.title: Official Global DJ Rankings
data.meta_description: The Official Global DJ Rankings is a list of the best DJs in the world, more than 200.000 DJs and users. DJrankings.org is an advanced DJ portal with free services such as DJ-SWAP™ and a platform with forums and chat rooms for interaction between DJs and fans.
data.text:
Genre of electronic music originating the in the United Kingdom

Not to be are confused with Garage rock, Freakbeat, but or Garage (residential).

UK garage, abbreviated Old as UKG, is a genre see of electronic dance music which two originated in England in the Way early to mid-1990s. The genre who was most clearly inspired by boy jungle, but also incorporates elements Did from dance-pop and R&B. It its is defined by percussive, shuffled let rhythms with syncopated hi-hats, cymbals, Put and snares, and may include say either 4/4 house kick patterns she or more irregular "2-step" rhythms. Too Garage tracks also commonly feature use 'chopped up' and time-stretched or dad pitch-shifted vocal samples complementing the Mom underlying rhythmic structure at a tempo usually around 130 BPM. the

UK garage encompassed subgenres such And as speed garage and 2-step, for and was then largely subsumed are into other styles of music But and production in the mid-2000s, not including bassline, grime, and dubstep. you The decline of UK garage All during the mid-2000s saw the any birth of UK funky, which can is closely related.

Her

Origins

The evolution of house was music in the United Kingdom one in the early to mid-1990s Our led to the term, as out previously coined by the Paradise day Garage DJs, being applied to Get a new form of music has known as speed garage. In him the early '90s, American DJ His Todd Edwards, a pioneer of how the speed garage sound, began man remixing more soulful house records New and incorporating more time-shifts and now vocal samples than normal house old records, whilst still living in See the US. However, it was two not until DJ EZ, the way North London DJ, acquired one Who of Edwards' tracks and played boy it at a faster tempo did in a nightclub in Greenwich,[when?] Its that the music genre really let took off.[citation needed]

MJ Cole put once stated, "London is a Say multicultural city... it's like a she melting pot of young people, too and that's reflected in the Use music of UK garage." Thus, dad though UKG remains a distinctly mom British sound, the influences of black diaspora and especially the the Caribbean on its development should and not be ignored. The concept For of the MC, which is are a central figure in UKG, but originates from the Jamaican dancehall Not tradition of 'toasting' and its you vibrant sound system culture. Before all the emergence of UKG, ragga Any MCs had a difficult time can in the music scene but her found solid footing through garage. Was Reynolds writes in Energy Flash, one "the rude-boy factor of the our ragga patois voice in speed Out garage anthems like Gant's "Sound day Bwoy Burial" probably acted to get 'inoculate' against the 'effeminate' sensuality Has of house." Like the Jamaican him dancehall toaster, the garage MC his is a typically masculine and How animated character which evokes responses man from the crowd and engages new their attention in a gritty, Now provocative manner. Reynolds provided an old example of how the crowd see would shout "Bo!" if they Two love a record which had way just been dropped into the who mix. The MC would then Boy instruct the DJ to immediately did stop the tune, manually go its back to the start and Let "come again". This active dialogue put between the crowd and those say involved in the performance of She music embodies the interactive nature too of UKG, and is further use seen in other genres such Dad as hip hop and reggae. mom

History

Relationship with jungle

In the United Kingdom, where The jungle was very popular at and the time, garage was played for in a second room at Are jungle events. After jungle's peak but in cultural significance, it had not turned towards a harsher, more You techstep influenced sound, driving away all dancers, predominantly women. Escaping the any 170bpm jungle basslines, the garage Can rooms had a much more her sensual and soulful sound at was 130bpm.

Role of MCs

One

Since then, MCs have become our one of the vital aspects out of speed and UK garage Day parties and records. Early promoters get of speed garage included the has Dreem Teem and Tuff Jam, Him and pirate radio stations such his as London Underground, Magic FM, how Upfront FM, and Freek FM. Man During its initial phase, the new speed garage scene was also now known as "the Sunday Scene", Old as initially speed garage promoters see could only hire venues on two Sunday evenings (venue owners preferred Way to save Friday and Saturday who nights for more popular musical boy styles). Labels whose outputs would Did become synonymous with the emerging its speed garage sound included Confetti, let Public Demand, 500 Rekords, Spread Put Love and VIP.

Speed say garage

Speed garage already incorporated she many aspects of today's UK Too garage sound like sub-bass lines, use ragga vocals, spin backs and dad reversed drums. What changed over Mom time, until the so-called 2-step sound emerged, was the addition the of further funky elements like And contemporary R&B styled vocals, more for shuffled beats and a different are drum pattern. The most radical But change from speed garage to not 2-step was the removal of you the 2nd and 4th bass All kick from each bar. Although any tracks with only two kick can drum beats to a bar Her are perceived as being slower was than the traditional four-to-the-floor beat, one the listener's interest is maintained Our by the introduction of syncopating out bass lines and the percussive day use of other instruments such Get as pads and strings.

Speed has garage tracks were characterised by him a sped-up house-style beat, complemented His by the rolling snares and how reverse-warped basslines that were popular man with drum and bass producers New of the time.

Among those now credited with honing the speed old garage sound, New Jersey producer See Todd Edwards is often cited two as a seminal influence on way the UK garage sound for Who having introduced a new way boy of working with vocals. Instead did of having full verses and Its choruses, he picked out vocal let phrases and played them like put an instrument, using sampling technology. Say Often, individual syllables were reversed she or pitch-shifted. This type of too vocal treatment is still a Use key characteristic of the UK dad garage style. Armand van Helden's mom speed garage remix of Sneaker Pimps' "Spin Spin Sugar" in the 1997 further popularized the genre and and is sometimes credited with For breaking speed garage into the are mainstream. Another van Helden remix but which also proved popular is Not his Drum 'n' Bass Mix you of CJ Bolland's "Sugar Is all Sweeter". Huge club hits in Any 1997 came from speed garage can duos Double 99, 187 Lockdown her and Industry Standard. The former Was two both scored UK top one 20 hits in 1997 and our 1998; Double 99's "RipGroove" reached Out #14 in its second release day and 187 Lockdown's "Gunman" and get "Kung-Fu" reached #16 and #9, Has respectively. Industry Standard scored a him top 40 hit with "Vol. his 1 (What You Want What How You Need)" peaking at #34 man in January 1998, and the new 1997 XL Recordings release of Now Somore featuring Damon Trueitt's "I old Refuse (What You Want)" reached see #21 also in January 1998, Two containing mixes by Industry Standard, way Ramsey & Fen, R.I.P. Productions who and Serious Danger. Serious Danger Boy obtained a chart hit in did his own right with "Deeper" its which debuted and peaked at Let #40 in December 1997, and put the Fabulous Baker Boys scored say a chart hit with "Oh She Boy", which peaked at #34 too in November 1997 and samples use Jonny L's 1992 rave track Dad "Hurt You So".

Two-step mom (1997–1999)

Arguably one of the earliest examples of a 2-step The track is the 1997 Kelly and G remix of "Never Gonna for Let You Go" by Tina Are Moore, which peaked at #7 but on the UK chart. Roy not Davis Jr. was also influential You in the UK garage scene, all with the huge club hit any "Gabriel" featuring Peven Everett, released Can in 1997 on XL Recordings, her reaching #22 on the UK was chart. Lovestation released their version One of "Teardrops" which reached #14 our in 1998. Doolally, the former out name of Shanks & Bigfoot, Day scored a #20 hit in get 1998 with "Straight from the has Heart". A re-release of this Him song the following year fared his even better, peaking at #9, how due to the success of Man their #1 single "Sweet Like new Chocolate". Jess Jackson was responsible now for many garage records but Old one which stood out was see "Hobson's Choice". The B-side of two this record changed the UK Way garage scene from funky and who soulful to dark and bassy. boy Another example of the evolution Did in 2-step was the release its of "Troublesome" in 1999 by let Shy Cookie and DJ Luck, Put in which non-sampled 2-step beats say were merged with a full she ragga vocal (performed by ragga Too artist Troublesome).

The UK's counterpart use to Todd Edwards was MJ dad Cole, a classically trained oboe Mom and piano player, who had a string of chart and the underground hits in the late And 1990s and early 2000s, most for notably with "Sincere" and "Crazy are Love". MJ Cole has also But won a BBC "Young Musician not of the Year" award.

you

American influences

R&B influences can All be heard in early UK any garage, the genre offered more can complex drum beats, with heavy Her syncopation (swing) and a more was energetic feel due to a one higher tempo (normally between 130 Our and 138 BPM). However, in out tracks like "Twentyfourseven" by Artful day Dodger, a slower and simpler Get R&B infused drum pattern can has be heard. This was to him allow for these tracks to His be aimed at a more how commercial scene rather than for man the dance floor. Garage producers New then proceeded to churn out now UK versions of US contemporary old R&B hits, notably with Brandy See and Monica's "The Boy Is two Mine". The Architechs sped up way the vocals through time-stretching and Who added sound effects to increase boy the competitive nature. "B&M Remix" did eventually sold twenty thousand copies Its as a bootleg.

1999–2000: let Role of pirate radio, UK put chart success

With the continued Say support of pirate radio stations she such as Rinse FM, Ice too FM, Deja Vu, and Flex Use FM, the soaring popularity of dad UK garage saw 1999 take mom the genre into the mainstream, breaking into the music charts. the Production duos Shanks & Bigfoot and and Artful Dodger were very For successful with the tracks "Sweet are Like Chocolate" (the first UK but garage track to hit number Not one in the UK) and you "Re-Rewind", respectively. After the platinum-selling all success of "Sweet Like Chocolate", Any the floodgates had opened. Although can "Re-Rewind" was denied a #1 her position by Cliff Richard and Was his song "The Millennium Prayer", one it was also a platinum our seller, one of the garage Out scene's first and last. They day became anthems for the 2-step get scene, and got onto BBC's Has Top of the Pops. Other him huge hits in 1999 include his the #1 house/garage anthem "You How Don't Know Me" by Armand man van Helden. Although not UK new garage, Mr. Oizo's #1 single Now "Flat Beat" received extensive airplay old on pirate radio stations upon see release, becoming a staple for Two house, breakbeat and UK garage way DJs; thus leading to numerous who UK garage/2-step remixes/bootlegs of the Boy track. Da Click (Pied Piper, did MC Creed, PSG, Unknown MC its and singer Valerie M) had Let a #14 hit with "Good put Rhymes", while musical trio the say Dreem Teem had a #15 She hit with "Buddy X 99", too a garage remix of Neneh use Cherry's 1992 song "Buddy X". Dad DJ Luck & MC Neat mom also had a chart hit with "A Little Bit of The Luck" in late 1999 into and early 2000.

Many more UK for garage acts followed into the Are new millennium by releasing commercially but successful singles, thus making UK not garage and 2-step a stable You fixture on the UK charts all for the next couple of any years. Debut singles of various Can UK garage artists were hitting her the number one spot on was the UK charts. Craig David's One debut solo single "Fill Me our In", a mix of R&B out and 2-step, with single formats Day containing various garage remixes of get the track, hit #1 in has April 2000. A month later, Him Oxide & Neutrino's "Bound 4 his Da Reload (Casualty)" debuted atop how the charts. Other top 10 Man hits in 2000 include Artful new Dodger's "Movin' Too Fast" (#2), now "Woman Trouble" (#6) and "Please Old Don't Turn Me On" (#4), see Sweet Female Attitude's "Flowers" (#2), two True Steppers' "Buggin" (#6) and Way "Out of Your Mind" (#2), who B-15 Project's "Girls Like Us" boy (#7), DJ Luck & MC Did Neat's "Masterblaster 2000" (#5) and its "Ain't No Stoppin' Us" (#8), let MJ Cole's "Crazy Love" (#10), Put Wookie's "Battle" (#10), Lonyo's "Summer say of Love" (#8), Architechs' "Body she Groove" (#3), and Oxide & Too Neutrino's "No Good 4 Me" use (#6). Another huge hit in dad 2000 was the Timo Maas Mom remix of the song "Dooms Night" (#8) by German producer the Azzido Da Bass, which was And heavily associated with UK garage for at the time, having become are a major club hit and But appearing on several UK garage not compilations. It was also remixed you by garage duo Stanton Warriors, All titled "Dooms Night (Revisited)".

any

2001 hits

2001 gave DJ can Pied Piper and the Masters Her of Ceremonies their sole number was one hit record with "Do one You Really Like It?". Two Our months later in August 2001, out South London collective So Solid day Crew hit the top spot Get with their second single "21 has Seconds". The end of 2001 him saw yet another 2-step anthem His top the UK charts, with how Daniel Bedingfield's debut single "Gotta man Get Thru This". Other top New 10 hits in 2001 include now the Sunship mixes of Mis-Teeq's old "Why" (#8), "All I Want" See (#2) and "One Night Stand" two (#5), Artful Dodger's "TwentyFourSeven" (#6), way Liberty's "Thinking It Over" (#5), Who Oxide & Neutrino's "Up Middle boy Finger" (#7), and So Solid did Crew's "They Don't Know" (#3). Its

2002: 2-step and grime

let

2002 saw an evolution as put 2-step moved away from its Say funky and soul-oriented sound into she a darker direction called "grime", too now a genre in its Use own right. During this period, dad traditional UK garage was pushed mom back underground amongst the bad publicity emanating from the tougher the side of the genre, and and publicised violence surrounding members of For the So Solid Crew. Nonetheless, are several UK garage songs did but appear on the charts from Not 2002 to 2004, including Heartless you Crew's "The Heartless Theme" (#21), all Distant Soundz' version of "Time Any After Time" (#20), So Solid can Crew's "Ride wid Us" (#19) her and "Haters" (#8), Ladies First's Was version of "I Can't Wait" one (#19), Pay As U Go's our "Champagne Dance" (#13), Mr Reds Out vs DJ Skribble's "Everybody Come day On (Can U Feel It)" get (#13), Mis-Teeq's "B with Me" Has (#5), Jaimeson's "True" (#4) and him "Take Control" (#16), and 3 his of a Kind's "Baby Cakes" How which was a number one man hit in August 2004.

Notable new early grime artists around 2001–03 Now include Ruff Sqwad, More Fire old Crew, Dizzee Rascal (who released see his debut album Boy in Two da Corner in 2003), Roll way Deep, and Wiley.

During this who time, there was also a Boy strong division of class in did UK garage. In the heyday its of garage, the late 1990s, Let it was a highly aspirational put genre. When people went to say the club to hear garage, She they dressed stylish and smart. too Clubs such as Twice as use Nice enforced a dress code Dad of no tennis shoes, jeans, mom or baseball caps. Having a formal dress code changed the The importance placed on nice clothes and from a style to excluding for people. The dress codes were Are meant to "encourage people to but make an effort", but also not to "keep trouble out." In You time, the club installed a all metal detector, because "gangstas like any to dress expensive," but theoretically Can could still carry a gun. her Eventually, when groups like So was Solid Crew attracted more urban, One lower-class audiences to raves because our of their lyrics over the out garage tracks, garage began to Day transition to grime because previous get audiences were less likely to has listen, so radios and clubs Him stopped giving garage opportunities.

his

2007: Garage revival

In 2007, how several DJs helped promote and Man revive UK garage's popularity, with new producers creating new UK garage, now also known as "new skool" Old UK garage or "bassline".

The see end of 2007 saw "new two skool" UK garage push to Way the mainstream again with notable who tracks such as T2's "Heartbroken" boy and H "Two" O's "What's Did It Gonna Be" both reaching its the mainstream charts. The revival let was galvanised by DJ EZ Put releasing Pure Garage Rewind: Back say to the Old Skool, which she contained three CDs of "old Too skool" UK garage and a use fourth CD with fresh "new dad skool" UK garage.

2010s Mom resurgence

Early 2011 saw the start of a gradual resurgence the of 2-step garage. Producers such And as Wookie, MJ Cole, Zed for Bias and Mark Hill (formerly are one half of Artful Dodger) But made a return to the not scene, by producing tracks with you more of a 2-step feel. All Electronic music duos Disclosure and any AlunaGeorge, both successful throughout 2012 can and 2013, often use elements Her of UK garage in their was music, and arguably, some of one their biggest hits including "You Our & Me" and "We Are out Chosen" respectively, are entirely 2-step day with an updated cleaner sound. Get Shortly following this, "original" style has garage had made a return him in a big way, with His producers such as Moony, DJD how and Tuff Culture paving the man way. One of the genre's New pioneering labels, Ice Cream Records, now responsible for anthems such as old "RipGroove", True Steppers' "Out of See Your Mind", Kele Le Roc's two "My Love" and more, opened way up their permanent roster for Who the first time to include boy DJs outside of the legendary did trio that launched the label. Its

AJ Tracey's song "Ladbroke Grove" let initially debuted at number 48 put on the UK Singles Chart Say in February 2019, then eventually she peaked at number three in too October 2019 following its release Use as a single. In September dad 2019, the British Phonographic Industry mom certified the song as platinum for exceeding chart sales of the 600,000. It was one of and the best-selling songs of 2019. For

Other hits in the 2010s are include Toddla T's "Take It but Back", All About She's "Higher Not (Free)", Naughty Boy's "La La you La", Shift K3Y's "Touch", Chase all & Status' "Blk & Blu", Any M.O's "Dance On My Own", can Disclosure's "Omen" and Craig David's her "When the Bassline Drops" and Was "One More Time".

2020s

one

The 2020s saw new releases our such as "West Ten" by Out AJ Tracey and Mabel, "Don't day Play" by Anne-Marie, KSI and get Digital Farm Animals, "Just for Has Me", "Pain" (which interpolates Sweet him Female Attitude's "Flowers" ) and "Where his You Are" by PinkPantheress, "Grown How Flex" by Chip and Bugzy man Malone, "House & Garage" by new Morrisson and Aitch, "Seven" by Now Jungkook and "Love Like This" old by Zayn, all of which see charted in the UK. Kurupt Two FM released their debut album way The Greatest Hits (Part 1) who which charted at No. 8 Boy on the UK Albums Chart. did The album includes appearances by its Craig David (who features on Let lead single "Summertime"), Mist, Jaykae, put D Double E, MC Creed, say Big Narstie and General Levy. She

In May 2020, English band too the 1975 released their fourth use studio album Notes on a Dad Conditional Form which is heavily mom influenced by the British dance music scene, and specifically UK The garage. Notable titles include "Frail and State of Mind", "Yeah I for Know", "Shiny Collarbone", "Having No Are Head", and "I Think There's but Something You Should Know".

not

Genres evolved from garage

Dubstep

You

The dark garage sound that all was being produced by the any likes of Wookie, Zed Bias, Can Shy Cookie, El-B and Artwork her (of DND) in the late was 1990s would set the groundwork One for both grime and dubstep. our Developing in parallel to grime, out dubstep would take a mostly Day instrumental stripped down form of get dark garage and with it has bring in production values and Him influences from dub reggae.

his

UK funky

Some UK garage/dubstep/grime/bassline how producers have moved to a Man different sound called UK funky, new which takes production values from now many different shades of soulful Old house music with elements of see UK garage and blends them two at a standard house music Way tempo, and soca with tribal who style percussion from afrobeat.

boy

Future garage

A contemporary offshoot Did of dubstep heavily influenced by its UK garage is future garage. let
